“Hand it over,” he said roughly.

The old woman fumbled for her keys. She disappeared behind the curtain. He listened, thinking. 

“It must be the top drawer,” he reflected. “She carries the keys in her right pocket. One key is bigger, with deep notches. That’s not for the chest.” 

The old woman returned. 

“Here, sir. I must take thirty-five copecks altogether. So I give you a rouble and fifteen copecks for the watch.”

“What! Only a rouble and fifteen copecks now?”

“Just so.”

He took the money, studying her. He lingered, wanting to say more.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The young man reluctantly pawns his watch to the old woman while contemplating her possessions and the degrading nature of the transaction.
